Development of the efficient MnOx/TiO2 catalysts with high dispersibility and stability of denitration reaction for NH3-SCR is crucial to control NOx emission at low temperature. Herein, we propose mineral polarization effect modification on the surface of MnOx/TiO2 denitration catalytic material via coprecipitation method using tourmaline as modifying agent, and evaluate its performance of NOx removal. Particularly, tourmaline-MnOx/TiO2 catalysts presented a high denitration rate about 97% under the condition of 1000 ppm NO, 1000 ppm NH3 and 5% O2 at 200 °C and maintained above 91% removal efficiency within 10 h, which was mainly ascribed to the polarization effect of tourmaline. The doping of tourmaline could improve the dispersion of catalytic materials, reduce the band gap width, and promote the activation of NH3 and the oxidation of NO. Moreover, the microscopic mechanism was studied by density functional theory (DFT) calculation from the aspects of adsorption energy, mulliken charge and density of states during the adsorption process. Overall, the results of this study will provide references for the application of mineral polarization effect to the field of denitration catalysis and promotes the further understanding of the mechanism for deNOx reaction process. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NOx Tourmaline MnOx/TiO2 catalysts DFT 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) have always been one of the major air pollutants around the world with the reason that the pollution gas can cause a series of atmospheric pollution problems such as ozone depletion and atmospheric acid deposition. Generally, NOx emissions are produced from stationary or mobile sources, including cement kilns, coal-fired power plants and vehicle engines [1]. Among them, the NO emission of cement kiln accounts for about 10%. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology is the most promising approach to remove NOx from cement kiln currently, Vanadia-loaded titanium dioxide catalyst (VOx/TiOx) has been widely applied in this area due to high deNOx efficiency in the range of 300–400 °C [2]. Nevertheless, this type of catalyst is restricted to high temperature operation conditions and thus is prone to poisoning and deactivation [3]. Accordingly, it is of great practical significance to exploit novel efficient and steady catalytic materials for the denitration process after desulfurization and dust removal at low-temperature. The transition metal oxides MnOx contains the vacant d-orbitals, which can effectively promote the adsorption of NH3 with lone pair electrons, and thus accelerate SCR denitration reaction at low-temperature, but in terms of the active ingredient, MnOx contains a small specific surface area and is vulnerable to the effect of sulfur poisoning. It has been reported that TiO2 as a carrier can slow down the crystallization of MnOx during the preparation process [4], promote the dispersion and reduce the formation rate of sulfate species, loading MnOx onto TiO2 exhibits excellent low-temperature denitration activity, which increased with an augment of Mn loading and reaction temperature. Niu et al. [5] demonstrated that the NOx conversion rate over MnOx/TiO2-based catalyst prepared by the sol-gel method could reached up to 85% at 220 °C in the presence of 700 ppm NO, 700 ppm NH3, 4 vol% O2 and balanced N2 (the total flow rate was 1 L·min−1) when the molar ratio of Mn/Ti is 0.4. However, K.M. [6] found that excessive addition of Mn loading (above 10%) would not improve catalytic activity anymore. Furthermore, this type of catalyst also has significant drawbacks, such as serious reunion phenomenon and easily deactivated. As reported by Wan et al. [7], although the initial NOx removal rate of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst could achieve 98% at 200 °C, the efficiency is gradually declined to below 50% after 100 h of denitration, which showing a relatively poor NOx removal stability, the reason why MnOx/TiO2 catalyst so inclined to deactivate is that the increased crystallinity and the aggregating phenomenon caused by long-term denitration. In consideration of the above problems, this paper considers adopting non-metallic mineral tourmaline as modifying agent to compound with MnOx/TiO2 denitration catalytic material and explore the specific influence, tourmaline powders possess the characteristic of spontaneous polarization, and there exist an 107v/m electric field around the tourmaline surface [8], which can promote the dispersion of particles. However, to the best of our knowledge, little literature has documented investigation in connection with the compound of tourmaline and denitration catalytic materials, most of the research primarily devoted it to the domain of photocatalysis. Fu et al. [9] demonstrated that tourmaline/TiO2 composite photocatalytic material can effectively remove heavy metal cations in experimental wastewater and degrade organic matter, the natural electric field around tourmaline particles can effectively reduce the recombination reaction rate between photogenerated electrons (e-) and photogenerated holes (h’), which could increase the efficiency of photocatalyst, so as to achieve a 99.5% Cu2+ removal rate and a Cd2+ removal rate of 99.9%. Moreover, tourmaline also has a vital influence on the nucleation and growth of the special material in the preparation process. Jin et al. [10] reported that when free electrons or ions exist on or around the tourmaline, the micro-electric field induced by its spontaneous polarization effect will promptly attract and capture it, causing it to lose its free mobility, and thus reduces crystallinity of the material and promotes the dispersion performance. In the present work, tourmaline was chosen as doping modifier to improve the dispersion of the MnOx/TiO2 catalyst and reduce agglomeration phenomenon, moreover, the microscopic mechanism of tourmaline effect on MnOx/TiO2 catalyst was also investigated by density functional theory (DFT) calculation from the aspects of adsorption energy, mulliken charge and density of states during the adsorption process. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts Manganese acetate and titanium oxide sulfate were dissolved into deionized water with a certain proportion (the molar ratio of manganese to titanium dioxide was 3:5) [11], and amount of tourmaline was added (accounts for 5%,10% and 20% of the powder mass, corresponding to MnOx/TiO2–5%, MnOx/TiO2–10% and MnOx/TiO2–20%).), the suspension was stirred at room temperature for 10 min and then ultrasound for 10 min. Afterward, appropriate amount of NH3·H2O was added into the solution as precipitant until the pH value was equal to 11, subsequently, instill 30% hydrogen peroxide dropwise until the solution color became uniform. After that, the resulting mixture was obtained by sucking filtration and washed several times with ethanol, the resulting powders were dried overnight and calcined at 350 °C for 3 h in air atmosphere, the final product was the MnOx/TiO2 catalytic material with different tourmaline content, the above medicines are all purchased from Beijing Yongneng Chemical Co., Ltd., and tourmaline is high-purity iron tourmaline. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystal structure of the catalysts was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.540598 Å) at a scan speed of 12° min−1. The specific surface area and pore structure were examined by N2 adsorption and desorption at 350 °C on a TriStar II 3020 high-speed automatic specific surface area and porosity analyzer made by Micromerics Company. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 with Al Kα X-rays (1486.7 eV). Binding energies were measured for O1s, Mn2p. C1s binding energy value of 284.6 eV was used as standard correcting the observed spectra to eliminate sample charging effects. 2.3 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance was evaluated on a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor containing a catalytic material dosage of 3 ml (a particle size of 40–60 mesh). The reaction gas condition was: 1000 ppm NH3, 1000 ppm NO, 5% O2 and N2 balance, the gas flow rate and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) were 200 mL/min and 27,000h−1, respectively. The concentrations of NO, NO2, NH3, N2O continually monitored by a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Thermo, Nicolet 6700 FT-IR) and Mass spectrometer (Extrel, MAX300-LG). The denitration activity of catalyst is represented by the NOx conversion rate, which was calculated according to the follow equation. η = ψ ( N O x ) i n − ψ ( N O x ) out ψ ( N O x ) in [ N O x ] = [ NO ] + [ N O 2 ] η − the N O x conversion rate ψ [ N O x ] in − the concentration of inlet NOx ψ [ N O x ] out − the concentration of outlet NOx The denitration stability test was performed on the denitration activity evaluation device under a nitrogen atmosphere at 200 °C for 10 h, and the change of NOx conversion rate was recorded every hour. 2.4 Calculation details According to the results of XPS and XRD analysis, the active substance of the catalyst was determined to be Mn3O4. Since titanium dioxide can increase the specific surface area of the catalyst as a carrier and the TiO2 (001) face shows higher catalytic activity, we reconstructed it by a (2 × 2) super cell as the carrier model. A vacuum gap of 10 Å aim was adopted to avoid the interference between different layers. When it is cleaned under vacuum conditions, a 3-layer slab is sufficient to ensure that the calculation will not too big within a certain range of the accuracy requirement because of its self-driven reconstruction. The bottom two layers were fixed to the bulk parameter during the optimization process. All the density function theory plus the dispersion (DFT-D) calculation were carried out through Dmol3 in the material studio 2017 (Accelrys, San Diego, CA, USA). Geometry optimizations were performed with the exchange-correlation functional GGA-PW91 and a double numerical basis set with polarization function (DNP) with spin unrestricted. The self-consistent field and gradient convergence energy was set to 2.0 × 10−5 hartree and 5 × 10−3 hartree/Å. The core treatment was set to effective core potentials (ECPs). The space cutoff radius was maintained at 4.6 Å. Brillouin zone was sampled by 2 × 2 × 1 k-points using the Monkhorst-Pack scheme. The transition state searching was performed with a complete linear synchronous transit (LST)/quadratic synchronous transit (QST). All the transition states (TS) were performed with imaginary frequencies. These TS state connected correctly to their individual reactant and product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 1 shows the SCR catalytic activity of the MnOx/TiO2 catalysts before and after modification with different additions of tourmaline (0%, 5%, 10% and 20% of total mass) in the temperature range of 90 °C-300 °C. As can be seen from the results, the denitration rate curve of the four different tourmaline loads increased first and then declined, the optimum denitration activity temperatures were all around 200 °C. For pure MnOx/TiO2 catalyst, the deNOx efficiency was the lowest in each temperature range, the efficiency achieved maximum with a removal rate of 88% when raised up to 200 °C, as temperature continued to rise, the efficiency began to decline. After addition of 5% tourmaline, the catalyst displayed higher activity, the NOx conversion rate on MnOx/TiO2–10% catalyst was higher than those over the other samples at the entire temperature range, up to 97% around 200 °C, nevertheless, further increasing the additive amount of tourmaline led to a negative influence on the NOx conversion rate, this might be due to the strengthening of interaction between excess tourmaline and thus aggravated the phenomenon of reunion. The characteristic of surface electric field generated by tourmaline spontaneous polarization is derived from its non-zero dipole moment [12], and the resulting electrostatic attraction makes it possible to adsorb, activate and redox gas molecules, which can improve denitration performance effectively. The denitration stability of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst with different tourmaline content at 200 °C for 10 h were presented in Fig. 2 . As we can see, the deNOx efficiency of pure MnOx/TiO2 catalyst dropped rapidly from the initial 92% to less than 80% after 10hours of denitration process, whereas, with the addition of 10% tourmaline, the original NOx removal rate was immediately increased to 97%, and after 10 h of deNOx process, the efficiency is still above 90%, meanwhile, consistent with the previous trend of denitration activity, the overall deNOx stability exhibited a variation of increasing first and then decreasing as the continuous increase of tourmaline addition, when the doping amount of tourmaline increased to 20%, the deNOx efficiency of MnOx/TiO2–20% dropped to only a little bit higher than that of the pure MnOx/TiO2 catalyst during the whole process of long-term denitration. The denitration selectivity is also an important evaluation factor of catalyst activity. The selectivity of the catalyst before and after tourmaline modification is shown in Fig. 3 . From the figure, it can be seen that the addition of tourmaline has no obvious influence on the selectivity of the catalyst, but the selectivity of the dosage with the best activity is even lower, which may be related to the change of the content of high valence manganese in the catalyst, which corresponds to the subsequent xps test results of Mn2p. On one hand, a proper amount of tourmaline can effectively promote the uniform distribution of particles in the preparation process, the spontaneous polarization of tourmaline not only contribute to the attraction between the particles due to the unsaturated bond, but also causes the phenomenon of repulsion and thus reduce agglomeration and change the valence state ratio of manganese [13]. On the other hand, tourmaline can effectively irradiate infrared to facilitate the activation of the reactant gas molecules, thereby improving the catalytic performance. 3.2 Structure characterization The phase composition of tourmaline and MnOx/TiO2 catalyst with different tourmaline fraction were characterized by XRD. As can be seen in Fig. 4 , the tourmaline corresponded to typical high-purity iron tourmaline with no other impurities. Meanwhile, Fig. 5 illustrates the obtained XRD patterns of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst with different tourmaline content, for the MnOx/TiO2 catalyst, the XRD analysis demonstrated that the main ingredient is anatase titanium dioxide and Mn3O4, and it could be seen that tourmaline did not change its crystal structure during the addition process and the diffraction peaks of Mn3O4 gradually strengthened and then weakened with the increase of tourmaline doping amount, it is established in the literature that [14] tourmaline possesses the property of spontaneously polarizing, which could promote the crystal nucleation and accelerate the growth of metal oxides during the preparation process, and consequently regulate the valence state of Mn and decrease the grain size of Mn3O4. Table 1 summarizes the specific surface areas, pore volumes and pore sizes of the samples. The specific surface area of MnOx/TiO2–5%, MnOx/TiO2–10% and MnOx/TiO2–20% was 88.3m2/g, 98.7 m2/g and 90.5m2/g respectively, showing a trend of increasing first and then decreasing with the increasing of tourmaline addition, which was consistent with the variation trend of denitration activity. This might be that when the tourmaline added in a small amount, the spontaneous polarization of tourmaline can effectively promote the uniform grain growth and grain refinement, resulting in an increase in the specific surface area. Nevertheless, with the content of tourmaline exceeded 10%, the interaction between the tourmaline particles was strengthened, which resulted in an agglomeration of itself, and the catalyst particles adsorbed on the tourmaline surface due to electrostatic attraction, thus reducing the specific surface area, eventually, exhibiting the regularity of MnOx/TiO2–5% < MnOx/TiO2–20% < MnOx/TiO2–10%. The NO removal performance is related to the critical factors such as the number and intensity of the denitration active sites, a larger specific surface area means better dispersion of the active ingredients and more exposed surface of the active component [15], which may also mean a higher denitration activity in some way. Textural properties of the MnOx/TiO2 catalysts with different tourmaline additions were obtained from isotherms of nitrogen adsorption at −195 °C. The pore size distribution was carried out in the range of 0 to 200 nm by applying the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT). As shown in Fig. 6 , the adsorption isotherms displayed a typical “IV” with H1 hysteresis ring, which indicated that the catalysts were mesoporous (5–50 nm) [16]and meant that the pore of the catalysts were uniform and narrow [17]. In the intermediate relative pressure region (0 < p/po < 1), the isotherm shape of the MnOx/TiO2 catalysts with different tourmaline additions presented a similar trend, which associated with the filling of mesopores. Moreover, the adsorption volume of MnOx/TiO2 modified by tourmaline is bigger than that of pure MnOx/TiO2 catalyst, the larger adsorption capacity means that more reactant gas could be adsorbed on the catalyst during the denitration process, which stands for higher denitrification activity, that's also one of the reasons why tourmaline can improve the deNOx performance of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. 3.3 Chemical properties analysis To obtain additional insight into the changes of surface chemical composition and cations valence states of the MnOx/TiO2 catalysts with different tourmaline additions, XPS measurement was employed to investigate the atomic concentrations and element chemical state of the layers close to the surface of catalysts. As seen in Fig. 7 , the Mn2p3/2 XPS spectra demonstrated two main peaks centered at 641.5 eV and 642.1 eV ascribed to Mn3+ and Mn4+species, respectively [18]. With the increase of tourmaline content, the proportion of trivalent manganese in the catalytic material increased first and then decreased, which mainly attributed to the properties of tourmaline for facilitating the transfer of electrons. Katiyar A et al. [19]have demonstrated that NH3 adsorbed on the active acidic site and took off one H proton to form NH2, then reacted with gaseous NO at the octahedral position of Mn3+, indicating that Mn3+ played an important role in the deNOx reaction [20]. Fig. 8 illustrates the obtained XPS spectra of O1s, and the corresponding surface atomic concentrations and the relative concentration ratios were presented in Table 2 . In Fig. 8, the O1s XPS spectra was fitted into two peaks assigned to the chemisorbed oxygen species at high binding energy (532 eV) and the lattice oxygen species at low binding energy (529.7 eV), donated as Oα and Oβ, respectively [21]. Surface chemisorbed oxygen primarily derived from the adsorption of oxygen molecule from the gaseous phase to the catalyst surface by chemisorption, on account of its higher mobility, chemisorbed oxygen is more active than lattice oxygen during the oxidation process, which can promote the oxidation of NO to produce NO2 and adsorb ammonia to dehydrogenate, consequently, the higher the ratio of Oα/(Oα+Oβ), the more conducive to improve the performance of denitration. As shown in Table 2, the value of Oα/(Oα+Oβ) in the MnOx/TiO2 catalyst increased significantly with the addition of tourmaline, which indicates that the negative oxygen ions released by tourmaline could promoted the generation of adsorbed oxygen and the transformation of lattice oxygen, thus resulting in the improvement of denitration efficiency. 3.4 DFT calculation 3.4.1 Model of MnOx/TiO2 In order to further investigate the micro-influence mechanism of tourmaline on MnOx/TiO2 catalytic material during the denitration process, the model of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst was established in Dmol3, as shown in Fig. 9 . Based on the previous analysis results, the main form of active component in catalyst was Mn3O4, the major carrier was anatase-TiO2, therefore, the construction of the catalyst model was selected as Mn3O4/TiO2, among them, a single Mn3O4 cluster was put on anatase-TiO2 (001) facet and then optimized, the lowest energy configuration was chosen for further DFT calculation [22]. On account of the complex crystal structure of tourmaline, and the impact of tourmaline on denitration process mainly derived from the surface electric field, the applied electric field(107V/m) [23] was used for representing the doping modification of tourmaline in Dmol3. 3.4.2 Deformation electron density The deformation electron density calculation was employed to explore the change of electrons transfer between gasses and MnOx/TiO2 catalytic material under the action of electric field during the SCR reaction, this method can simultaneously reflect the electron cloud density change of adsorbate and adsorbent under the adsorption state compared with that in the free state. The specific calculation method is as follows: Δ ρ = ρ g a s / s u b s t r a t e − ρ g a s − ρ s u b s t r a t e where the ρgas and ρsubstrate represent the charge densities of gas molecules and catalytic materials in free state, respectively, ρgas/substrate represents the overall charge density of the system after gas was adsorbed on the surface of the catalytic material, Δ ρ is the difference value of the electron density before and after adsorption. The obtained geometries model of electron cloud density transfer for NO and NH3 molecules adsorbed on the surface of the Mn3O4/TiO2 catalyst before and after the addition of electric field were shown in Fig. 10 and Fig. 11 , respectively. The light blue and yellow positions in the figure indicate that the charge density decreases or increases after adsorption compared with the free state, respectively. According to the definition of differential charge, the negative position in the image is the region where electrons diverge, and the positive position is the region where electrons converge. As we can see in the Fig. 10 and Fig. 11, the NO molecule was inclined to adsorb above the Mn atoms with its O end, simultaneously, the NH3 molecule was liable to adsorb above the Mn atoms with its N end. From Fig. 10(a), when the NO was adsorbed on the surface of the catalytic material before modification, the electron cloud density of N atom along the N-O bonding direction increases, while that of other regions decreases. The regional electron cloud density of O atom close to the active component decreases obviously, indicating that no stable chemical bond has been formed. In contrast, among the active component, the charge density of Mn atom has both decreased and increased parts, which are caused by varying changes in charge density on account of different energies in each individual atomic orbital [24]. For the modified catalytic material, it can be observed from Fig. 10(b) that the charge density of N and O atoms in NO gas molecule decreases significantly after adsorbed on the catalyst surface under the action of electric field, the blue area is apparently larger than the adsorption of NO to the catalytic material without electric field, which demonstrate that the NO molecule loses more electrons and becomes more oxidized. In addition, the density of electron cloud bonding between N and O increases, indicating that the intermolecular bonding force of NO becomes stronger. It is worth noting that the literature researches indicate that [25] adsorbed NO can only react with adsorbed NH3, but hardly couple with NH3 exist in the gas phase directly. Based on the information, we speculate that when there's a lack of NH3 in the system, NO will be adsorbed on the surface of the catalytic material and oxidized by lattice O to form nitrate, preempting the active site of the catalytic material, and impeding the occurrence of SCR reaction, obstructing the adsorption of other gasses. On account of its considerable stability, the nitrate will occupy the active site on the surface of the catalytic material and make it passivated under 500 K, hinder further denitration reaction process, which is the reason for the poor denitration stability of catalysts at low temperature. Whereas, the toxicity of these nitrates on the catalyst is related to temperature, as the temperature rises above 650 K, nitrates will gradually decompose as intermediate product of SCR reaction and will not deactivate the catalyst [26]. When NH3 exists in the system and adsorbed on the catalyst, the adsorbed-NO will react with the activated NH4 + or the coordination state NH3 to form the intermediate product NH2NO or NH4NO2, and finally decompose into N2 and H2O, complete the entire REDOX reaction cycle. Fig. 11 shows the deformation electron density for NH3 molecule adsorbed on the surface of the Mn3O4/TiO2 catalyst before and after the addition of electric field, as shown in Fig. 11(a), when the NO was adsorbed on the surface of the catalytic material before modification, the electron cloud density of the bond position between NH3 molecule and Mn atom as well as the trigonal plane direction formed by N and H atom decreased, nonetheless, the density of the electron cloud increases significantly at the position of the lone pair of N atom, the electrons in ammonia molecule concentrate on N atoms, while the H atoms tend to dissociate at the same time. After the addition of electric field (Fig. 11(b)), the deformation charge density diagram of NH3 adsorption changes in a similar way, the distinction is that the charge density in the bonding direction between NH3 molecule and the active component decreases more obviously. During the whole process of NH3 adsorption to the surface of the catalytic material, since the 3d orbital of Mn atom possess vacant orbitals, it tends to attract electrons, which is exactly the N atom of NH3 contains lone pair electrons, therefore, in the denitration process, NH3 molecule is inclined to close to Mn atom, providing lone pair electrons to form coordination bonds with it and forming a stable chemisorption structure [27]. Due to the higher electronegativity of Mn atom, the electrons that form the N-H bond in NH3 molecule tend to transfer to Mn atom, resulting in the stability of the N-H bond reduces and the H proton dissociates more easily, as a result, the NH3 molecule is activated by the catalytic material to form the coordination state NH3, which is convenient for the subsequent reaction with NO. As for the simultaneous increase and decrease conditions of charge density around Mn, how it changes is extremely difficult to uncover by the current deformation electron density calculation, the overall gain and loss of electrons requires further analysis by calculating the Mulliken charge. 3.4.3 Mulliken charge populations Mulliken charge populations calculation was employed to quantitatively analyze the distribution and transfer condition of the electron between adsorbates and adsorbents [28], as illustrated in Table 3 , the Mulliken charge populations of the NO and NH3 at free state as well as the charges after adsorbed on the surface of Mn3O4/TiO2 catalysts before and after modification are listed. The larger charge value of the same atom after adsorption indicates that a certain number of electrons are lost in the adsorption process, on the contrary, the decrease of the charge value indicates that a certain number of electrons are gained. For the NH3 molecule, the charge of NH3 at the free state was 0.001 e and the charges of N, H1, H2 and H3 were −0.517 e, 0.172 e, 0.174 e and 0.172 e, respectively, while the overall charge of NH3 becomes 0.515e after adsorption on the surface of the Mn3O4/TiO2 catalytic material without electric field, indicating that 0.514 electrons of NH3 molecule are lost during the adsorption process, and the charge numbers of N, H1, H2 and H3 become −0.325 e, 0.271 e, 0.283 e and 0.286 e, respectively. However, for the catalytic material with the addition of electric field, the overall charge of the gas molecule after NH3 is adsorbed on its surface becomes 0.485 e, which means that 0.484 electrons are lost in the adsorption process, in the meantime, the charge numbers of N, H1, H2 and H3 become −0.331e, 0.263 e, 0.266 e and 0.286 e, respectively. In the process of adsorption to the surface of the catalytic material, the whole NH3 molecule manifests itself as losing electrons, both constituent N and H atoms are losing electrons likewise, in which the electron loss number of H3 is significantly greater than that of H1 and H2 atoms. In the presence of electric field, NH3 molecule loses fewer electrons when adsorbed to the catalyst, it is mainly manifested as the number of electrons lost by H1 and H2 atoms decrease, which indicates that H3 atom tends to dissociate from NH3 molecule. When NH3 molecule removes the H3 atom, it is activated and easily couple with NO rapidly, thus effectively remove the harmful gas NO, meanwhile, the bonds between N and H1, H2 atoms could become stronger under the action of electric field, which will further promote the subsequent reaction with NO [29]. Then pay attention to the charge changes of Mn and Ti atoms on the surface of catalytic material after NH3 adsorption, the charges of Mn and Ti on the surface of catalytic material which are not adsorbed by gas are 1.143 e and 1.613 e, after adsorption, the charges become 1.043e and 1.315e, respectively. The atomic charges of Mn and Ti are reduced by 0.1e and 0.298 e, respectively. Nevertheless, the charge of Mn and Ti on the surface of the catalytic material with the addition of electric field changed to 1.013 e and 1.572 e after NH3 adsorption, and the atomic charge of Mn decreased by 0.13 e, and that of Ti decreased by 0.041 e, both atoms obtained a certain number of electrons, exhibiting a Lewis acidity. With regards to the NO molecule, the charge of NO at the free state is 0.002 e and the charges of N and O are 0.355 e, −0.353 e, respectively, the charge number of NO molecule should be 0 e- in the ideal condition, and the charge values of N and O atoms should be equal. While after NO molecule adsorbed on the surface of Mn3O4/TiO2 catalytic material, its overall charge rose to 0.214 e, losing 0.212 electrons, the charge number of N atom rose to 0.617 e and the charge number of O atom decreased to −0.403 e, as a result, 0.262 and 0.05 electrons were lost and obtained for N and O atoms, respectively, indicating that the oxidation of NO molecule was mainly aroused by the electrons loss of N atom. With the addition of electric field, the overall charge of NO molecule became 0.571 e when adsorbed on the catalyst, 0.569 electrons were lost and NO was oxidized, the charge numbers of N and O atoms became 0.795e and −0.214 e, respectively, the number of electrons lost by NO molecules, N and O atoms were more than that without electric field, illustrating that the modification of tourmaline could promote the catalytic material to acquire more electrons from NO molecule, and NO was oxidized more thoroughly during the reaction process. After adsorption of NO molecule, both the Mulliken charge population of Mn and Ti atoms in the catalyst have a certain degree of change, for the pure Mn3O4/TiO2 catalyst, the charge of Mn atom merely has tiny rose after NO adsorption, about 0.012 electrons lost, while the Ti atom received 0.121 electrons, after adding the electric field, the situation of Mn atom changed from losing electrons to acquiring electrons, which indicates that the electric field could promote the electrons transfer to Mn atom and strengthen its Lewis acid activity, meanwhile, the number of electrons acquired by Ti atom decreased. 3.4.4 Densities of states Fig. 12 illustrates the density of states diagram of Mn3O4/TiO2 catalyst before and after adding electric field, the electrons exist in two states: spin-up and spin-down, in this study, we only pat attention to the situation of spin-up. From Fig. 12, one can obviously notice that the band gap of pure catalyst is 1.05 eV, which is larger than that of electric-catalyst(0.57 eV), as a result, the energy gap of Mn3O4/TiO2 catalyst decreased from 1.05 eV to 0.57 eV when electric field was imposed, in addition, it is observed that the conduction band shifts to the Fermi level for electric-catalyst, and the energy level above Fermi level is mainly from Ti 3d orbital with few contributions from Mn and O atom, whereas the valence band is mainly provided by the orbitals of O and Mn atoms, merely with few contributions from Ti states. The lower the energy distribution of the lowest non-occupied orbital, the easier it is to accept electrons, showing a stronger Lewis acidity [30]. The addition of electric field could reduce the width of the forbidden band, promote the transition of electrons, and accelerate the transfer of electrons between valence band and conduction band. After the electronic transition, the enhanced activity can activate NH3 and form holes at the original position. Because of the existence of lone pair electrons, N atom in NH3 molecule tend to approach holes and form coordination bonds after approaching, thus promoting the adsorption and activation of NH3. The peak shift of the density of states and the overlap of the same waveform represented that there exists hybridization between adsorption molecule and substrate. The whole density of states after NH3 adsorption is shown in Fig. 13 . It can be seen from the figure that although the band gap narrows for catalytic materials without electric field, there is still a band gap at Fermi level, while after NH3 adsorption by catalytic materials with electric field, all Fermi level is occupied by electrons, which shows that electrons in this part can move freely due to the addition of electric field, and their movement is unrestricted, thus making it easier to participate in the follow-up redox reaction. Fig. 14 shows the PDOS of the NH3 in free state and after adsorption on Mn3O4/TiO2 catalyst with or without electric field. It is observed that the density of states peak near Fermi level disappears with NH3 adsorption, which demonstrates that lots of electrons were transferred from NH3 molecule to the surface of catalyst, when adsorbed on the surface of catalytic material, the Fermi level of NH3 and the peak state density at −5 eV all moved to the direction of lower energy on the left, which indicates that NH3 molecule lost electrons and existed strong interaction with the surface of catalytic material. Nevertheless, when NH3 adsorbed on the catalytic material surface with electric field, the peak at Fermi level moved further to the left low energy state, indicating that more electrons were lost. In the meantime, the peak shape was obviously broadened, demonstrating that the delocalization and activity of electrons were enhanced [31]. The overall density of states after NO adsorption is shown in Fig. 15 . It can be seen from the graph that the overall trend after NO adsorption is analogous to the situation of NH3 adsorption. For catalytic materials without electric field, although the band gap narrowed, there was still a band gap at Fermi level. However, when the NO adsorbed on the catalytic material after adding electric field, the density of states exceeded Fermi level, and all Fermi level was occupied by electrons. These shows that the electrons movement was unrestricted in the adsorption system and they can move freely due to the addition of electric field, making it easier to participate in the subsequent redox reaction. The electron densities of the s and p orbitals of NO molecule were shown in the Fig. 16 , which are correspond to the sum of the electron densities of the s and p orbitals for the N atom and O atom, respectively. Different from the case of NH3 adsorbed on the surface of catalyst, the energy interval of partial density distribution of s and p orbitals of NO adsorbed on the surface of catalyst did not shift obviously, the sole change is that the delocalization of each position became stronger, indicating that NO became more active after adsorption, the addition of electric field could promote the electronic activity of NO and accelerate the reaction. After adding the electric field, the density integral area of NO state decreases and more electrons are lost, which indicates that the degree of NO oxidation is aggravated by catalyst under the action of electric field. 4 Conclusions The impact of mineral polarization effect of tourmaline on denitration performance of MnOx/TiO2 catalytic material was studied by XRD, BET, XPS analysis and DFT calculation. The original NOx removal rate was immediately increased to 97% at 200 °C when the tourmaline content was 10%, and after 10 h of denitration process, the efficiency is still above 90%. Appropriate amount of tourmaline could increase the specific surface area, oxygen content and trivalent manganese content of the catalyst, thus resulting in the improvement of denitration efficiency. In addition, according to our previous experimental results, the model of Mn3O4 cluster loaded on the TiO2(001) surface with external electric field was chosen to consider the microscopic mechanism of the tourmaline polarized effect on catalyst. Both NH3 and NO molecule lose electrons after being adsorbed on the catalyst surface, the N-H bond of NH3 is more prone to fracture and the NH3 molecule is activated accordingly, meanwhile, NO is oxidized during adsorption. Furthermore, the external electric field made the energy gap decrease further, the energy gap decreased from 1.05 eV to 0.57 eV, which reduced the difficulty of electron transition, in the meantime, the delocalization of electrons increases in the process of NH3 and NO adsorption on the catalyst surface, which accelerated the activation of NH3 and the oxidation of NO, thereby improving the denitration efficiency. Overall, the doping of tourmaline significantly enhanced the low-temperature SCR activity and stability of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst, which could be a strategy for the further design of SCR catalysts, and consequently more detailed studies are needed to comprehend the microscopic mechanism between the effect of mineral polarization and MnOx/TiO2-based catalysts during NH3-SCR process. coredata.dc:description: Development of the efficient MnOx/TiO2 catalysts with high dispersibility and stability of denitration reaction for NH3-SCR is crucial to control NOx emission at low temperature. Herein, we propose mineral polarization effect modification on the surface of MnOx/TiO2 denitration catalytic material via coprecipitation method using tourmaline as modifying agent, and evaluate its performance of NOx removal. Particularly, tourmaline-MnOx/TiO2 catalysts presented a high denitration rate about 97% under the condition of 1000 ppm NO, 1000 ppm NH3 and 5% O2 at 200 °C and maintained above 91% removal efficiency within 10 h, which was mainly ascribed to the polarization effect of tourmaline. The doping of tourmaline could improve the dispersion of catalytic materials, reduce the band gap width, and promote the activation of NH3 and the oxidation of NO. Moreover, the microscopic mechanism was studied by density functional theory (DFT) calculation from the aspects of adsorption energy, mulliken charge and density of states during the adsorption process. Overall, the results of this study will provide references for the application of mineral polarization effect to the field of denitration catalysis and promotes the further understanding of the mechanism for deNOx reaction process.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of tourmaline on the denitration performance of MnOx/TiO2 catalysts and DFT calculation
